Award.AwardTitle: High-Redshift Black Hole Mass Measurements with Multi-Object Reverberation Mapping
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quasi-stellar objects (QSOs) are the cores of distant galaxies whose extreme activity is powered by black holes that may be billions of times the mass of our Sun. The team will study how the optical emission from distant QSOs varies over time. If a QSO's light emission brightens quickly, the surrounding gas will brighten after a time delay that depends on its distance from the black hole. This is the basis of reverberation mapping. The team will measure the time delays for the gas to brighten in a number of QSOs. By modeling the time delay for each QSO, the team will determine the mass of its black hole and the structure of the surrounding gas. They will also develop shortcuts for estimating black hole masses for distant QSOs. Senior team members will train junior members. The public will be informed about the fascinating subject of massive black holes through public talks, social media, and planetarium show content.

The team will complete a multi-year campaign of photometric and spectroscopic monitoring of nearly 800 high-redshift QSOs. Their goals are to (1) use reverberation mapping to measure the black hole masses of the QSOs; (2) study the structure of the broad emission-line regions of the QSOs; and (3) develop secondary ways of estimating black hole masses for the population of QSOs at high redshift.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcomes of this project were to use the reverberation mapping technique to measure 1) the masses of supermassive black holes in distant quasars and 2) the sizes of quasar accretion disks. This is interesting and important because reverberation mapping is the only way to measure the masses of supermassive black holes outside of the local universe, and consequently to learn the origin of these enormous black holes and how they grew in size over the lifetime of the universe. This is especially important to study in distant, high-redshift quasars that existed when the quasar space density was over 1000x greater than it is in the universe today, because this is when most supermassive black hole growth occurred. In addition, reverberation mapping is one of the few ways to measure the sizes of accretion disks, as they cannot be spatially resolved in such distant objects, and there remain many unanswered questions about the nature of accretion onto supermassive black holes.

We monitored nearly 800 quasars for six years to achieve our objectives, and in the process we recorded over 120 photometric measurements and over 25 spectroscopic measurements of these quasars. We analyzed the photometric data to measure accretion disk sizes for approximately 30 quasars, which is a substantial increase in the number of measurements. The main outcome of this part of the work was an important confirmation of the conventional theory for the structure of these disks. These results are contained in two papers that have been published in peer-reviewed journals. We also used both the photometric and spectroscopic measurements to measure the sizes of the CIV and MgII broad emission line regions in many quasars, and another outcome was that we obtained some of the best measurements of the sizes of these regions in high-redshift quasars. These measurements are critical to measure the masses of high-redshift supermassive black holes and to better establish the empirical relationships that are used to estimate the masses for samples of thousands to hundreds of thousands of quasars. This is because it is impractical to obtain sufficient data for reverberation mapping analysis on so many objects, and consequently scaling relations are the best tool to measure the origin and evolution of supermassive black holes over the history of the universe. These results are contained in three additional papers that have been published in peer-reviewed journals, and a fourth article that is submitted and undergoing review.

In the course of these measurements, we developed many new analysis methods and conducted numerous studies with simulated data to verify our measurements, and to better quantify the uncertainties in our results. These are carefully described in two, dedicated papers. One is published in a peer-reviewed journal article, and the other is undergoing review for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. These methods have been employed in the analysis of the results on broad line region sizes and should become benchmarks for future, similar studies. This project also partially supported an interesting investigation into the potential of reverberation mapping measurements to better measure cosmological distances, which could help to measure the cosmic expansion history and explore the nature of dark energy. This work is presently undergoing review for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. Lastly, this project provided support to two graduate students during their dissertation work. One of these students successfully defended their thesis during the course of this project, and the other is scheduled to graduate in two more years.
